column78: I feel I cannot 'agree' or 'disagree' with most of the above statements simply because I have not asked nor observed instructors views on such questions.

column18: I do not have any teaching experience.
column50: Open Learning Faculty Members have been a vital part of the Open Textbook process, so I have learned through them.
column65: At this point, I'm not familar with the literature surrounding the efficacy of Open Textbooks, so I can't speak intelligently to whether ot not they increase engagement or learning outcomes. However, from people I have spoken with, I have gathered the impression that the materials are at least as good as those from a major publisher. Moreover, I personally think they have better potential than publisher materials, in the long term, as faculty or Open Learning Faculty Members have the ability to customize materials that are more relevant to the students that they instruct.
column79: TRU, Open Learning has been described as "punching above their weight" when it comes to OER. I'm proud of what has been done at my institution in regards to OERs
column81: I would like to see, if appropriate, a preference towards Open Textbooks whenever possible. From an administrative point of view, I believe the savings that they offer students can help keep TRU competitive and desirable to students.
column82: A sentiment that has been shared, privately, is that OER's may hurt instructors financially. I think this comes from an idea that giving away for free takes away from the ability for instructors to bring in extra money. Whether this is true or not, is unknown to me, but I suspect it is a misinformed opinion. I think addressing that concern is important, as it is one of those problems that individuals may privately think, but be afraid to say publiclly. I think it will be important for mass buy-in of use of OERs
column83: I've seen it and I know what it means
column85: Is a philosophical idea that education should be available to all, regardless of life circumstances or previous academic standing
column88: I think that as long as there is etiquette involved and instructors reach out to others, before altering their work (our of courtesy) that there should be no reason to keep materials private. Information should be public.
column89: I think that the financial risk may scare some individuals, regardless of whether it is true or not.

column79: Commitment to employ OER material (e.g., textbooks) whenever possible.  Founding member of OERU
column81: Centralized catalog/repository of OER material with student/peer reviews of quality and efficacy.
column82: Unaware; believing they have to actually change practices, e.g., technology; learn new material
column83: I've seen it but I don't know what it means
column85: The freedom to use/apply content to curriculum; the freedom to add to or otherwise augment existing material with the ability to share that augmented material with others.
column86: Yes, they should be publicly viewable but they shouldn't have a license on them that allows them to be revised and reused.
column88: Public viewing is in line with the 'openness' of OER; the ability to license suggests ownership, which is contrary to the 'openness' of OER.  Authors should expect being cited for any additions/creations of OER material, however.
column89: Licensing fees; bragging rights; loss of unique value for their course.

column85: Open access with academic supports to support student success; flexible delivery methods; prior learning credit with low residency requirements - in short removing any barriers to education
column86: Yes, they should be publicly viewable and they should have a license on them that allows them to be revised and reused.
column88: Very much like the sharing of open source code, I believe that sharing of educational resources will enhance the quality of the materials, promote the instructors knowledge and work,  and lead to reduced efforts in developing courses.

column88: Resources themselves do not do the teaching. Making resources available online can draw attention to teaching best practices that happen here at TRU.
